column1: #Text=The synthesis of polycrystalline Na2RuO3 consisted of two steps, following similar procedures present in Refs. 19 and 24.
#Text=The first part involved the synthesis of Na2RuO4, prepared by solid state reaction from stoichiometric amounts of Na2O2 and RuO2.
#Text=The powders were ground and mixed in an agate mortar under argon.
#Text=The mixture were placed in an alumina crucible and heated to 450 ◦C for 5 h, 530 ◦C for 10 h and 630 ◦C for 20 h under oxygen atmosphere with a temperature rate of 50 ◦C/h.
#Text=The phase composition of the resulting powder was checked using a Rigaku Miniflex 600 x-ray pow-der diffractometer, with the resulting diffraction pattern showing pure Na2RuO4 phase.
#Text=The second step consisted of reducing the Na2RuO4 under argon flow at 950 ◦C for 24 h using a tube furnace.
#Text=The resulting product was a black homogeneous Na2RuO3 powder, which was found to be mildly air sensitive.
#Text=Efforts to make single crystals via flux growth were unsuccessful, due in part to the volatility of the material and the requirement of having a reducing atmosphere to stabilise the Ru4+ ion.
